headline.main: Of the Palate, From the Palette

docs.lead_paragraph: "ART WHAT THOU EAT," a display of 19th- and 20th-century American paintings and sculpture at the New-York Historical Society through March 22, makes a good case for developing an eating disorder. Eating too much -- or not eating at all -- is one of the few ways that individuals can still exert some control over the corporate takeover of American food supplies that is depicted here. The connection to food production is, after all, an Everyman sort of link to nature. Without it, people are as vulnerable as unfettered skiffs in a squall. When appetite is no longer a response to choosing among foods of one's own making, it becomes an amorphous urge easily co-opted by industry. TV dinners, junk food, liquid diets, microwave ovens and McDonald's are the beachheads in corporate America's assault on idiosyncratic taste. I
